options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Clearly stating what you can and can't do.

options.label: D
options.text: Giving them a sense of control.

options.text: Clearly state what you can and can't do.

options.text: Give them a sense of control.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.text: They are not capable of connecting with others.

options.label: D

options.text: We should avoid talking to them altogether.

options.label: C
options.text: We should interact with them in a genuine and supportive way.

options.label: D
options.text: We should only talk to them about their depression.

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Three ways the universe could end - Venus Keus

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Bang theory's explanation for the universe's past?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion is accelerating at an accelerated rate.

options.label: B
options.text: All matter, time, and space began in an incredibly tiny, compact state about 14 billion years ago.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is heading for a Big Freeze.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe's shape is determined by the amount of dark energy it holds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Freeze scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe continues to expand at an accelerated rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion slows down, and galaxies separate.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe's expansion is reversed, and galaxies start rushing towards each other.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe's expansion is halted, and then it starts expanding again.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion slows down, and galaxies separate.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion is reversed, and galaxies start rushing towards each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The repulsive force is so strong that it tears apart galaxies and solar systems.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe's expansion is halted, and then it starts expanding again.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion slows down, and galaxies separate.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion is reversed, and galaxies start rushing towards each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The repulsive force is so strong that it tears apart galaxies and solar systems.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe's expansion is halted, and then it starts expanding again.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion is accelerated at an accelerated rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe could expand and contract over and over again, repeating its entire history.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe's shape is determined by the amount of dark energy it holds.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe's expansion is halted, and then it starts expanding again.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion is accelerated at an accelerated rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion slows down, and galaxies separate.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe's expansion is reversed, and galaxies start rushing towards each other.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe becomes dark and cold, approaching a frozen state.

options.text: The attractive force of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: The repulsive force expanding the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: The electromagnetic force.

options.label: D
options.text: The strong nuclear force.

options.label: B
options.text: They break apart and are destroyed.

options.label: C
options.text: They start rushing towards each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They are halted and then start expanding again.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe becomes dark and cold, approaching a frozen state.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion is reversed, and galaxies start rushing towards each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe's expansion is halted, and then it starts expanding again.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It offers a more nuanced understanding of identity and human experience

options.label: C
options.text: It critiques the myth of national identity and the idea of "going back" to one's country of origin

options.label: D
options.text: It proposes a new way of thinking about identity and nationality

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that Taiye Selasi is trying to convey in her conclusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of nationality in shaping identity

options.label: B
options.text: The limitations of the "where are you from?" question

options.label: C
options.text: The complexities and multiplicities of human experience

options.label: D
options.text: The myth of national identity and the idea of "going back" to one's country of origin

title: Why should you read Shakespeare's "The Tempest"? - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is the setting of The Tempest?

options.label: B

options.text: A city in Asia

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: How do ocean currents work? - Jennifer Verduin

multiple-choice.question: What was the origin of the rubber ducks used to chart a better understanding of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: A cargo ship carrying them from the equator to the North Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: A cargo ship carrying them from the North Pole to the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: A cargo ship carrying them got caught in a storm and washed overboard.

options.label: D
options.text: A cargo ship carrying them from the southern hemisphere to the northern hemisphere.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main categories of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Surface currents and atmospheric currents.

options.label: B
options.text: Surface currents and deep ocean currents.

options.label: C
options.text: Wind currents and tidal currents.

options.label: D
options.text: Thermal currents and saline currents.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary driver of surface currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Changes in water density.

options.label: B
options.text: Wind and tides.

options.label: C
options.text: The rotation of the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: The Coriolis Effect.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Coriolis Effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The movement of air from the equator to the North Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: The movement of air from the North Pole to the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: The deflection of air from the equator to the North Pole and vice versa due to the Earth's rotation.

options.label: D
options.text: The movement of air from the southern hemisphere to the northern hemisphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: A surface current that flows from the equator to the North Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: A deep ocean current that flows from the North Pole to the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: A winding loop of deep ocean currents and wind-driven surface currents.

options.label: D
options.text: A thermal current that flows from the equator to the North Pole.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Global Conveyor Belt help to redistribute warmth around the globe?

options.label: A
options.text: By moving warm water from the equator to the North Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: By moving cold water from the North Pole to the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: By moving warm water from the surface to the deep ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: By moving cold water from the deep ocean to the surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rate at which the Global Conveyor Belt moves?

options.label: A
options.text: A few meters per second.

options.label: B
options.text: A few centimeters per second.

options.label: C
options.text: A few millimeters per second.

options.label: D
options.text: A few kilometers per second.

multiple-choice.question: What are the implications of the Global Conveyor Belt slowing down?

options.label: A
options.text: It would cause the Earth's climate to warm up.

options.label: B
options.text: It would cause the Earth's climate to cool down.

options.label: C
options.text: It would cause weather systems on both sides of the Atlantic to change.

options.label: D
options.text: It would have no impact on the Earth's climate.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to continue studying ocean currents and the powerful forces that shape them?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the movement of the Earth's plates.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the movement of the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: To forecast and prepare for changes in the Earth's climate.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the movement of the Earth's oceans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the rubber ducks that washed overboard in 1992?

options.label: A
options.text: They were used to study the movement of the Earth's plates.

options.label: B
options.text: They were used to study the movement of the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: They were used to study the movement of the Earth's oceans.

options.label: D
options.text: They were used to study the movement of the Earth's climate.
